title: Something in the Way Fest 2026: Live updates from Roadrunner
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Something in the Way festival at Bostonâ€™s Roadrunner features two dozen indie and alt-rock bands.
Sunny Day Real Estate is the main attraction for Day 2 of the two-day music festival.
Performers like Her New Knife and Graham Hunt used sets to voice political opinions on ICE and immigration policies.

title: Why the Bruins practiced in a tent on Saturday in Florida
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bruins practiced in a tent at Raymond James Stadium to maintain ice quality before outdoor game in Florida.
The tent, 34 feet high and 125 feet wide, was designed to control temperature and humidity for ice preservation.
NHL implemented measures like a thicker ice surface and refrigeration to combat Florida's weather conditions.

title: Boston ‘ICE Out Everywhere’ protest must-see moments
author: Annie Jonas and Samantha Genzer
bullets: Thousands gathered at Boston Common on Jan. 31, 2026, protesting state cooperation with ICE and supporting immigrant rights.
The rally was part of a national campaign involving over 300 cities, inspired by recent deaths linked to ICE agents.
Protesters demanded state legislation to limit ICE operations in sensitive areas like schools and health care facilities.

title: Photos from Boston’s ‘ICE Out Everywhere’ protest
author: Kelly Chan
bullets: Over a thousand people in Boston protested Trump's immigration policies at the 'ICE Out Everywhere' rally on Boston Common.
The protest, organized by Mass 50501, occurred nationwide following Friday's 'National Shutdown' to oppose ICE actions.
Protesters gathered near the State House, despite 15-degree temperatures and recent snowfall, to voice opposition to ICE.

title: Insider believes Red Sox have ‘another move in them’ this offseason to improve infield
author: Conor Roche
bullets: ESPN's Jeff Passan suggests the Red Sox are likely to trade for a new infielder before the 2026 season.
Boston prioritizes defensive infield help, considering Isaac Paredes and Christian Walker as potential trade targets.
Red Sox evaluated Cubs' Nico Hoerner and Matt Shaw, but trades are uncertain; internal options include Marcelo Mayer.

title: Even Drake Maye’s dad is surprised by Patriots’ Super Bowl run
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Patriots reach Super Bowl LX after a surprising turnaround from back-to-back 4-13 seasons under coach Mike Vrabel.
Quarterback Drake Maye played a key role, with an MVP-worthy regular season, posting a 72% completion rate and 4,394 passing yards.
Maye's playoff performance has been less impressive, but Patriots will face Seahawks in Super Bowl LX in Santa Clara.

title: That guy on TV, Cris Collinsworth, will look familiar to Patriots fans tuning into NBC to watch the Super Bowl
author: Chad Finn
bullets: Cris Collinsworth will call his 53rd Patriots game, alongside Mike Tirico, during Super Bowl LX on NBC.
Collinsworth has broadcasted five Super Bowls involving the Patriots, including their 2014 win over the Seahawks.
Collinsworth highlighted the Patriots' diverse strategies this season, reminiscent of their past dynasty years.

title: Mass. snowplow driver who spotted legs sticking out of snowbank praised for saving older man
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Snowplow driver Matte McGarry rescued an older man trapped in a 3-foot snowbank in Auburn, Massachusetts.
The man became stuck face-down in snow while walking home after a Patriots game during a storm.
McGarry will receive a commendation from the Auburn Board of Selectmen for his life-saving actions.

title: UMass student suspended after organizing protest sues university
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: UMass Amherst student Kivlighan de Montebello sues university after a one-year suspension for organizing a protest.
The protest targeted defense contractor RTX during a campus career fair, questioning its military ties.
De Montebello's lawsuit argues the suspension infringes on First Amendment rights and seeks damages and suspension removal.

title: More details emerge about children charged with murder in R.I.
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Four preteens charged with murder in connection to the fatal beating of Rony Alonso, 51, in Providence.
The juveniles, including three 12-year-olds and one 11-year-old, were initially charged with felony assault and conspiracy.
Charges were upgraded to murder after Alonso died on Jan. 22; all suspects were arraigned in Family Court.
